repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: We use the `p_force_on` and `p_force_off` variables to check if a variable is immutable and what its default value is. This is not only hacky and unintuitive, but also is limited to only boolean options.

Solution: Replace `p_force_on` and `p_force_off` with an `immutable` property for options, which indicates if an option is immutable. Immutable options cannot be changed from their default value.

Ref: #25672.

comment_data.body: It's a bit of a step backwards if we need to re-introduce dummy vars for disabled options. It would be better if it was the other way around, i e we would be able to delete `p_enc` etc while keeping the existing user-facing behavior.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -429,6 +429,7 @@ EXTERN unsigned cb_flags;
 EXTERN OptInt p_cwh;            ///< 'cmdwinheight'
 EXTERN OptInt p_ch;             ///< 'cmdheight'
 EXTERN char *p_cms;             ///< 'commentstring'
+EXTERN int p_cp;                ///< 'compatible'

comment_data.body: Why not simply disallow _setting_ an immutable option?

> Why not simply disallow _setting_ an immutable option?

Because the old behavior is to allow (silent ignore) setting it if the value is the same as before. If breaking backwards compatibility is fine, then I have no problems with simply not allowing the value to be set
I don't think this comment should be moved.

What about the `opt->immutable && optval_equal` case? Should it skip early, to avoid any "side effects" from `opt_did_set_cb`? Or are those actually needed (`let &foo=&foo` is an old trick but idk if it applies to immutable options)?
There is no side effect, the function returns shortly after.

The "side effects" are all in `else if` blocks, none of which are executed due to the `if` block already being executed. The part after that `if` chain checks if errmsg is nonnull, and if it is, it restores the old value and returns.

And to answer your second question, no, we don't need to make it more "explicit". There are multiple places in the `if` chain which set `errmsg` Also, we need to restore the old value before returning, and doing so for each `if` block would be needlessly repetitive.

> none of which are executed due to the `if` block already being executed

I'm talking about the `optval_equal` case, not `!optval_equal`. Why wouldn't the side effects be executed in that case?

Ah, I see what you mean now. I misread your earlier comment. Apologies for that. I still think we should execute side effects in that case because that's the case for any non-immutable option as well, as well as the current behavior for all options.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(options): replace `p_force_(on|off)` with `immutable`
